ExhTitle: A History of the North East in 100 Objects
NarNarrative:
37.

,

Wombat, Vombatus ursinus, 1798       

,

 

,

This is the first wombat to arrive in Europe. It was sent to Newcastle by Captain John Hunter, the Governor of New South Wales, in 1798. Wombats were first discovered by non-natives when the crew of the salvage ship Francis visited Australia?s Clarke Island following the wrecking of the ship Sydney Cove in 1797. On their third and final salvage trip the crew collected one specimen of this unusual marsupial.

,

 

,

The late 1700s, when the wombat arrived, heralded an exciting time for the study of natural sciences. Western Europe was a centre of scientific endeavour, promoting global exploration leading to the discovery of new flora and fauna. The arrival of the wombat in Newcastle helped our region to play a pivotal role in these discoveries, fostering and facilitating the study and understanding of novel plant and animal species.

,

 

,

Donated by Captain John Hunter (Governor of New South Wales), 1798

,

Mounted by Richard Wingate, 1827

,

                                                           

,

On display at the Great North Museum: Hancock, Explore! gallery (Collecting and Collectors case), Tyne & Wear Archives & Museums

,

Website www.greatnorthmuseum.org.uk

,

 

,

Image caption ? Tyne & Wear Archives & Museums

NarNarrative: The domestic ferret is a descendant of the Asiatic Polecat, a species which is found throughout eastern Europe, north Africa and Asia. It has been kept by humans as a domestic animal for over 2000 years. It was traditionally used to hunt rabbits, which are one of its main prey items in the wild. Ferrets are still used for this purpose in many areas, but today most ferrets are kept as pets.

Golden Moles are a group of burrowing mammals native to southern Africa. They have no eyes and spend most of their time burrowing beneath the surface. Their bodies are covered in dense, shiny golden fur. The Giant Golden Mole is the largest species. It lives in a few small areas of forest in the western cape of South Africa. It is an endangered species thought to be threatened by deforestation.

NarNarrative:
Imitation

,

The pangolin is an animal which has been imitated by humans because of its clever defences. Can you see the scales on both the armour and the pangolin. The overlapping scales give protection from other animals while still being easy to move in. This is why humans have made armour the same way.

,

Pangolin

,

When the pangolin feels scared it rolls up into a ball. Mother pangolins carry their babies on their backs for up to five months to protect them until their scales fully harden.

,

Lamellar Armour

,

This type of armour is called lamellar, meaning it is made of smaller pieces that overlap when tied together. This piece is made from metal which indicates tha tthe owner was wealthy.
LocalSum: East Africa, Tanganyika Territory, Dar Es Salaam

NarNarrative: The Aardvark takes its name from an Afrikaans word that, literally translated, means 'earth pig'. It is a large pig-like animal with a long snout. It lives in a wide variety of habitats in southern Africa, where it feeds on termites. Its front legs have powerful claws which are used to break open termite mounds. Aardvarks are nocturnal and spend the day asleep in a burrow.
SciName: Orycteropus afer : Orycteropodidae : Tubulidentata : Mammalia : Chordata

NarNarrative: These rat sized annimals live in dense undergrowth in the forests of eastern and central Africa, feeding on insects etc. in the leaf litter. They have a variety of different calls, ranging from cat-like purrs to squeaks.

American Bull mounted. Old bull, last of original pure stock in herd at Haggerston Castle, Northumberland.
NarNarrative: The American Bison is a large herbivore that originally lived on the plains of North America. It formed vast herds and at it's peak the population is estimated to have numbered about 30 million - possibly the largest population of land mammals to have lived in recent time. European settlers decimated the population and in 1890 it numbered just 750 animals. Legal protection resulted in the recovery of the population to the current level of about 80,000 in parks and reserves.
LocalSum: UK, England, Northumberland (NE England), Haggerston Castle

ColPhysicalDescription: Wild goat mounted, standing, head facing foreward, fore legs on stone.

NarNarrative: The arctic hare, or blue hare, is a widespread resident of northern and upland areas throughout Europe, Asia and North America. It feeds on low growing vegetation. It is also an important prey species for many larger predators. It can run very fast in order to escape these predators, reaching up to 80 km per hour. In arctic regions, the hare grows a coat of white fur in the winter to help to disguise it against the snow.

ColPhysicalDescription: Mount of a Hedgehog. Western Hedgehog
NarNarrative: The Hedgehog is a familiar sight all over Britain. It is a small, nocturnal mammal with a coat of sharp spines. Hedgehogs prefer areas with lots of dense cover. They are often found in deciduous woodland but have also adapted to suburban areas where there are lots of mature shrubs and trees. They eat a wide variety of insects and soil invertebrates such as earthworms. They are famous for their ability to curl up into a ball when threatened., The Hedgehog is a familiar sight all over Britain. It is a small, nocturnal mammal with a coat of sharp spines. Hedgehogs prefer areas with lots of dense cover. They are often found in deciduous woodland but have also adapted to suburban areas where there are lots of mature shrubs and trees. They eat a wide variety of insects and soil invertebrates such as earthworms. They are famous for their ability to curl up into a ball when threatened.
SciName: Chordata & Mammalia & Insectivora & Erinaceidae & Erinaceus europaeus : : : : Chordata

NarNarrative: The coypu is a large semi-aquatic mammal that is found throughout South America. It lives in marshes and also around lakes, rivers and streams. It digs a burrow near water and spends most of the day asleep, emerging in the early evening to feed on aquatic vegetation. The coypu has webbed hind feet that make it an expert swimmer. It has been introduced to many parts of the world and has become a serious pest in some areas.

ColPhysicalDescription: Grey seal mounted, lying in a seal case on the central platform. Skull in skin.

NarNarrative: The lion is the largest species of cat. It lives in Africa, and can be found in a wide variety of habitats. Lions live in social groups called prides. These consist of several females and their young. There are also usually one or two dominant males. Lions depend on large herbivores for food. They hunt co-operatively to catch antelope and other large animals weighing up to 300 kg.
LocalSum: UK, England, Tyne and Wear, Newcastle upon Tyne, Town Moor

ColPhysicalDescription: Skin of a Polar Bear, standing head lowered slightly. Named Eric.
NarNarrative: The Polar Bear is the largest land predator and lives throughout the arctic region. It grows to huge sizes. Some individuals reach over 600 kg in weight. Its main prey is the Ringed Seal, which it catches mainly by lying in wait next to seal breathing holes in the ice. Polar bears travel long distances following seal populations. Although not considered to be threatened, populations are difficult to monitor due to the inhospitable nature of much of the bears' habitat.

NarNarrative: This red deer antler is probably only a few hundred years old and not a true fossil. However, antlers are sometimes found in peat beds that formed about 7500 years ago as the climate warmed up after the last glaciation. The deer migrated into the once glaciated areas as the vegetation grew. The horns that are cast off annually are often the only remains that are found of the deer. EWJ

In the right upper jaw, furthest from the camera, one of the deciduous teeth is about to be shed - the new permanent tooth can be seen underneath it, pushing it out.

NarNarrative: The only wires which support this specimen are under its tail, which is very fragile. The rest of the bones are held together by the dried sinews which have been left in place for this purpose.

These Jumping Hares are about the size of Rabbits but the skull is typical of Rodents in general, with 2 large incisor (front) teeth and four chewing teeth altogether. The left lower one has slipped out of place and should be the same length as its pair.

ColPhysicalDescription: Skull, missing mandible, teeth, earbones. Sockets for 8-9 teeth on each side. May be female or immature from size.

NarNarrative: Spiny Anteaters, like the Platypus, are egg laying mammals. They are only found only in Australia and New Guinea. Like other ant eating mammals they have no teeth and an elongated snout. The usual adult size is 46=60cm (18=24ins) long. The female incubates her single egg in a depression in the skin of her underside. When it hatches the baby stays there and licks the creamy milk from the pores of the skin. It leaves the pouch when its spines begin to grow.

ExhTitle: Matt Stokes Exhibition - Great North Greats
NarNarrative: This anteater skull shows the tubular snout typical of all ant or termite eating mammals. The Giant Anteater is the largest of the true anteaters, growing to 1.8M (6 ft). Its sticky tongue can be 60cm (2ft) long. It roams through the grasslands of South America, searching for termites and ants. Its long curved front claws are strong enough for it to walk on, as well as being essential for ripping open the tough nests of its prey.

ColPhysicalDescription: Skull attached to shell-like skin of back.
NarNarrative: Armadillos have scale-like hardened skin on the back and sides of their bodies, and on the tops of their heads. The Hairy Armadilloes also have coarse hairs growing between these scales. They can draw in their legs and tail and flatten themselves against the ground for protection, and some varieties can roll themselves up into an armoured ball. They eat insects and sometimes plants and small vertebrates.

This hedgehog skull shows the teeth of typical insect eating mammals in the Old World. They are in the form of a row of pointed teeth, suitable for grasping and biting into the hard outside layers of insects. They also eat slugs and earthworms. They live in woodland, but have adapted to garden life. Like the armadillos, they can roll up into a ball for protection by their spiny hairs.

This skull has the typical row of pointed teeth of an insect eating mammal. Bush babies live in trees, and only hunt at night, so they have large eyes also, for seeing well in the dark, and the big forward-looking eye sockets can be seen in this skull. The front teeth are comb-like, and are probably used for grooming their fur.

ColPhysicalDescription: Skull (missing 6 incisors and lower right canine).

NarNarrative: The body of this six year old Chimpanzee, which died in Billy Smart's Circus, ended up at Mr. McCulloch's veterinary surgery. It was sent to the Hancock Museum where the bones were prepared and mounted as they are in the picture.

ColPhysicalDescription: Cranium, 15x5.0 cm area broken from upper part.
LocalSum: UK, England, Tyne and Wear (NE England), South Shields, Marsden
UK, England, Tyne and Wear (NE England), South Shields, Marsden

NarNarrative: Most of the information about this skull is written on its side. When Mr. Heighton of Kettering presented it to the Museum it was noted in the original handwritten Accession Book. He also gift geological specimens from Hitchin and Kettering. This skull was from a prehistoric burial in the Rothwell area.

Jackals belong to the dog family in which the front teeth are used for grooming and cleaning the coat. They are also used to help the four long and sharply pointed teeth, known as dog (canine) teeth, grasp the newly caught prey. At the back of the mouth are the large scissor-like teeth used for slicing up the food, which is swallowed in chunks. These teeth can also scrunch up smaller items, such as large insects or small bones. If you have a pet dog you will have seen it doing most of these things.

There are three views of this skull, showing it in side view, with some of the front teeth showing, and a view of the chewing surfaces of all the teeth. Unlike most carnivores there are no slicing teeth at the back of bears' jaws, only blunt grinding (bunodont) teeth.

ColPhysicalDescription: Skull (missing 3 upper incisors, 2 premolars and 2 molars).

NarNarrative: This is a complete badger skull. The teeth are adapted to dealing with a wide range of food. Insects, other invertebrates, small mammals and reptiles, fruits and other plant matter, and carrion are all part of their diet. In the British Isles and northern Europe, earthworms are the most important component of their food, while in southern Europe badgers eat mostly insects and fruits.

This is the skull of a domestic cat which was acquired by the museum after it was killed in a road accident. The large eye sockets are typical of an animal which in the wild would depend on excellent vision to catch its prey. The sharp, pointed canine teeth are also typical of a predatory animal.
LocalSum: UK, England, Tyne and Wear, Newcastle upon Tyne

ColPhysicalDescription: Skull and hyoid with 9 bones. Breeding female with milk in mammary glands.
NarNarrative: This skull is from a Grey Seal and came from the Farne Islands off the coast of Northumberland, UK. Grey Seals are predators and eat between four and six percent of their body weight in one feeding per day. The diet consists of a large variety of fish and the occasional crustacean (lobsters, shrimps and prawns) and molluscs (squid).
LocalSum: UK, England, Northumberland (NE England), Farne Islands

ColPhysicalDescription: Beak and wings and feet,parts of.
Skull missing jugals, ear bones and 15-20 teeth; right lachrymal broken off. The total number of teeth present is approximately 180.
NarNarrative: This Dolphin skull shows the long jaws with a formidable array of teeth. There are 80-120 teeth per jaw. Common Dolphins range in size from 1.7m to 2.6m, and weigh between 70kg and 135kg. Common Dolphins prey on schooling fish (e.g. herring, pilchards) and squid. They have been known to adopt co-operative techniques when hunting (rather like the Orca) and have also been observed catching fish in mid-air.

LocalSum: UK, Scotland, Western Isles, Isle of Lewis, Port of Ness

NarNarrative: This is the tooth of a Sperm Whale which became stranded on a beach near Cresswell, Northumberland, UK about 1724. The sperm whale is found in groups known as pods. Its brain weighs about 9 kilos (20 pounds), the largest brain of any lving animal. The sperm whale produces oil in its spermaceti organ which enables it to dive to great depths without getting the 'bends'. This oil was once used in car engines.

ColPhysicalDescription: Skull (missing teeth, jugals and ear bones) and vertebrae (about 29).
LocalSum: UK, England, North Tyneside, Tynemouth Haven

NarNarrative: This is part of the skeleton of a Sei Whale which was beached near Amble, Northumberland in February 1912. Sei whales are baleen whales and feed by sieving mouthfuls of water through their plates of baleen and swallowing the fish that are left.
LocalSum: UK, England, Northumberland (NE England), Amble (beach south of)

ColOtherName: New World Monkey, New World Monkey
ColPhysicalDescription: Skeleton, mounted (missing parts of tail and digits).
NarNarrative: This is the mounted skeleton of a Tamarin monkey. It may have been a pet that was gift to the Hancock Museum when it died. Lion tamarins are so named from a mane derived from long hairs on the top of the head, cheeks and throat. Sadly this beautiful animal is in danger of extinction. In the 19th century, it was widespread in Brazil in the coastal forests of the states of Rio de Janeiro and Espirito Santo. By the early 1980's it was known only from remnant forests in the state of Rio de Janeiro in an area considerably less than 900 sq km (350 square miles).

NarNarrative: This very large tooth belonged to an Indian Elephant. It is a molar, a large tooth at the back of the lower jaw. Elepahnts feed on plants and the large flat surface of the elephants teeth are well adapted for grinding up plant stems and leaves.

NarNarrative: This Zebra skull is almost complete. Zebras belong to the horse family, hoofed animals characterized by one toe. This includes all horses, and horse-like animals of the world. This single hoof is probably an adaptation for fast motion on hard ground. Zebras are found throughout eastern and southern Africa. They feed on grasses, leaves and twigs.

NarNarrative: The Duck-billed Platypus lives in Eastern Australia and Tasmania. It lives in and around rivers. It digs a burrow in the river bank and spends most of its time diving into the water to catch insect larvae and other invertebrates. It keeps its eyes shut when it is underwater. This means that it has to use it's large bill to locate prey. The bill is very sensitive and can detect tiny electrical signals given off by the prey animals.

ColPhysicalDescription: Mounted specimen of a Sloth Bear standing upright. The bear's front limbs are curved around a wooden post.
SciName: Melursus ursinus : Ursidae : Carnivora : Mammalia : Chordata

ColPhysicalDescription: A Canada Lynx mounted in a standing position with back arched, one front paw raised and it's mouth open in a fierce display. Standing on a small base.
NarNarrative: This species is a medium sized cat which is native to the mountainous and forested regions of Europe and Asia. The fur on the feet is very thick which is an adaptation to the cold that also has a 'snowshoe' effect, allowing the lynx to travel easily over the surface of snow drifts and move faster when pursuing its prey, such as deer or goats.
SciName: Lynx canadensis : Felidae : Carnivora : Mammalia : Chordata

ColPhysicalDescription: Mount of a Red Necked Wallaby, possibly the Bennett's Wallaby subspecies, in an upright pose with head facing to the right.The tip of the tail is damaged.
SciName: Macropus rufogriseus : Macropodidae : Diprotodontia : Mammalia : Chordata

NarNarrative: The water vole is a large rodent that lives throughout Britain. It digs a system of burrows in the banks of rivers and streams. The water vole prefers to feed during the day, and eats a variety of plants. Also known as Water Rat though not related to true rats

The rabbit is now a familiar and widespread animal. However, before human interference, the rabbit was probably only found in central Spain. The Romans domesticated the rabbit and took it with them as they expanded their empire. In this way rabbits became established elsewhere in Europe. The rabbit was introduced to Britain in the 12th century. It has also been introduced to Australia, New Zealand and Chile where it has become a serious pest.

The Common Shrew is a small insectivore that is found throughout central and northern Europe and across Asia as far as lake Baikal in Russia. It lives in a variety of different habitats including moorland, forests and rough grasslands. Common shrews occur from sea level up to high altitudes in some mountainous areas. They feed mainly on beetles but will also eat other insects and invertebrates. They are also an important prey species for many larger predators, such as owls.

The House Mouse is a small and highly adaptable rodent. Originally it was probably a native of the forests and grasslands of southern Europe and central Asia. However, it has become well adapted to living in human environments and has spread along with humans all over the world. The house mouse can now be found on all continents except Antarctica and on most inhabited islands. It has become a serious pest of stored foodstuffs in some areas.

LocalSum: UK, England, Lincolnshire (Midland England), Skegness, Gibraltar Point
UK, England, Co. Durham (NE England), Consett, Woodlands Hall

ColPhysicalDescription: Mount of a Porcupine, Crested Porcupine
NarNarrative: Crested Porcupines have long black and white quills and long wiry hair on the head and shoulders. The quills are used as a defence. They are found in savanna in Africa and Asia.

The Red Howler is a large monkey that lives in the rainforests of South America. It's diet consists mainly of leaves and fruit. Red Howler monkeys live mainly in small groups. They take their name from their extremely loud call, which is amplified by a special throat pouch and a bone in the throat that acts as a resonator. The call is used to communicate with other groups of monkeys over long distances across the forest.

ColPhysicalDescription: Head only of a hunter's hartebeest.

NarNarrative: The chimpanzee is native to the forests of western and central Africa. It is one of the most closely related species to humans and shares over 97% of our genes. Chimpanzees live in large social groups and show many signs of intelligence. They can use tools such as rocks to crack open nuts, co-operate to hunt monkeys and have over 30 different calls. This individual is a juvenile.

The Caribou is the name given to the Reindeer found in North America. Reindeer live in northern and arctic regions throughout northern Canada, Greenland, Alaska and Siberia. They are social animals and live in large herds of up to several thousand animals. These herds migrate north during the short summer and then retreat south as temperatures drop in autumn to avoid the harsh winter. They are a very important source of food and livelihood for many arctic people.

ColPhysicalDescription: Red Panda mounted on a branch.
NarNarrative: The Red Panda, or lesser panda, is very different from the more familiar black and white species. It is a small animal that spends most of its time high up in the forest canopy. It lives in forested mountain areas throughout the Himalayas, as well as Burma and Laos. Red pandas eat bamboo, acorns, roots and berries. They are mainly solitary and spend most of the day asleep. Red Pandas are an endangered species, mainly due to habitat destruction.
SciName: Ailurus fulgens previous family name Procyonidae : Ailuridae : Carnivora : Mammalia : Chordata

NarNarrative: The Pine Marten is found in mature forests throughout northern Europe and western Russia. It is an agile climber and hunts small mammals and birds both in trees and on the ground. It is a solitary animal and is mainly nocturnal. In the past, Pine Martens were hunted for their fur and persecuted by gamekeepers who saw them as a threat to game stocks. This led to a large decline in numbers. Recent protection has led to some recovery.

The Roe Deer is the smallest species of deer native to Europe. It is found in broad leaved forests throughout Europe and Asia, It is a solitary species and is mainly nocturnal. Roe deer are browsers, and mainly eat leaves but will feed on a variety of fruits, fungi and grass when these are available. They are preyed on by jackals and wolves where these species occur, but in many parts of western Europe their only predator is man.

ColPhysicalDescription: Red Deer mounted, standing with forelegs on stone above ground.
NarNarrative: In North America it is known as the Elk or Wapiti. It feeds on a variety of leaves and grasses. Red deer live in herds, with a dominant female leading a herd of does and fawns. Males leave these herds at two or three years of age and normally join herds of 'bachelor' males. During the autumn breeding season these herds break up as males compete for females.

ColPhysicalDescription: Grey Squirrel mounted and standing on a branch.
NarNarrative: The grey squirrel is native to the oak and hickory forests of eastern North America. During the 19th century small numbers of grey squirrels were introduced to the UK. They rapidly spread and replaced the native British red squirrel in most areas. There are now thought to be more than 2 million grey squirrels in the UK. Major control efforts are underway to reduce the population and protect the remaining population of red squirrels.

ColPhysicalDescription: Wild Cat mounted, in the Wild Cat case. Set up by S. Cook and altered by T. Morgan.
NarNarrative: The Wildcat is widespread across Europe in forested areas, but has been heavily persecuted, particularly by gamekeepers. In Britain it is now only found in the Scottish highlands. Wildcats are larger than domestic cats and have a shorter tail. They are mainly nocturnal and feed on small mammals, birds and sometimes fish. There is a high degree of interbreeding between wildcats and domestic cats in many areas. This means that pure bred wildcats are now probably very rare.

ColPhysicalDescription: Edible Doormouse mounted (old mount), perched on a twig with a damaged ear. Skull in skin.
NarNarrative: The Edible or Fat Dormouse is similar in appearance to a small grey squirrel. It lives in mature woodlands throughout central and eastern Europe. In Britain there is a tiny population in southern England that was introduced during the last century. The dormice become very fat in the autumn, as they gorge themselves on nuts and seeds to prepare for hibernation. The Romans considered these fat dormice a delicacy and often served them at banquets, hence the name Edible Dormouse.

The Wild Boar is a large pig that is found throughout Europe, Asia and in parts of North Africa. It lives in forests where it forages for a wide variety of foods. The Wild Boar lives in small groups with one dominant male. The male can be very aggressive, particularly during the mating season when males fight over females. They have sharp tusks that are used in fights. The wild boar is also the ancestor of the domestic pig.

ColPhysicalDescription: Mount of Pink Fairy Armadillo standing.
NarNarrative: The Pink Fairy Armadillo is the smallest armadillo species. It lives in the hot, dry grasslands of central Argentina. It feeds mainly on ants and it is often found near ant hills. It is a solitary animal and spends most of the day underground in its burrow, emerging at night to feed. The conversion of land for agriculture has had a dramatic effect on the population of Pink Fairy Armadillos, and they are now an endangered species.
LocalSum: F.C.P. Argentina, V. Valeria, La Portena

ColPhysicalDescription: Mink mounted, standing with back arched.
NarNarrative: The North American Mink is native to forests throughout temperate North America, normally associated with lakes and rivers. Mink feed on small mammals such as rabbits and mice. Their very dense fur has made them popular with the fur industry, and they are farmed in Europe and Russia. Unfortunately many animals have escaped and established feral populations in some areas. In Britain they pose a serious threat to some native birds and mammals such as the Water Vole.
LocalSum: UK, England, Northumberland (NE England), Ponteland, Ponteland Mink Farm
Europe, France, Savoie, Vallee De Ribon

ColPhysicalDescription: Stitching falling apart on the throat.

LocalSum: UK, England, Northumberland (NE England), Greenhaugh, Highgreen Manor

MulDescription: Walrus trophy head in the Trophy Head store of the Great North Museum Resource Centre.

ColPhysicalDescription: Sheep mounted, standing on grass, branded in blue, skull in mount.
Frontlet of a white tailed gnu.

NarNarrative: This species of seal is found around the shores of Iceland, the Faeroe islands, Britain, Ireland, and parts of Scandinavia. It also occurs in eastern Canada. It feeds mainly on fish. The Grey seal spends a lot of time at sea, coming ashore to breed. It forms large breeding colonies, preferring small rocky islands away from human disturbance. Males are larger than females, and the bull seals defend a small territory and mate with all the females within it.
LocalSum: UK, England, Northumberland (NE England), Farne Islands
